paragraphs.text: Afghanistan at crucial juncture.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: On Thursday, the so-called London Conference on Afghanistan will convene
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Of all the high-profile international conferences that have been held on Afghanistan over the years- in Bonn, Tokyo, and Istanbul - this comes at a crucial juncture
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: At the end of October, British forces lowered the flag at Camp Bastion - from where they had engaged in the most intense fighting the British army had seen since the Falklands War- and handed over the base to Afghan forces
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Just over a month later, the Taliban mounted a 14-hour attack on the very same site, killing six Afghan soldiers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: To the north, in the capital Kabul, insurgents have pulled off a dozen attacks in the space of the last few weeks, striking at diplomats, NGOs, and US contractors
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: What explains this spate of violence, and is it a portent for the future of Afghanistan?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The International Security Assistance Force (ISAF), a US-led group that includes NATO members and others, winds up its mission on New Year's Eve
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: A slimmed-down force of 12,000 foreign troops - mostly American - will stay behind
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: US President Barack Obama has authorised the US contingent to continue supporting Afghan National Security Forces (ANSF) throughout 2015, with all of these forces scheduled to leave by the end of 2016
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The US is not, therefore, leaving Afghanistan in the abrupt manner than it left Iraq in 2011
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But this is a time of dramatic change
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Drastic effects on casualties
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: For one thing, the ANSF are doing much of the fighting themselves, with drastic effects on casualties
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: over 9,000 Afghan troops have died since 2013, four times greater than the entire American death toll since 2001
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Afghan police officers are suffering especially badly, with thousands being killed every month
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: At the political level, a new government of national unity, led by President Ashraf Ghani and Chief Executive Abdullah Abdullah, has taken charge after Hamid Karzai's departure
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Ghani is already reported to have opened backchannel talks with the Taliban, visiting both Pakistan and Beijing to seek their help in this effort, cancelling an earlier arms request from India, and even making a highly unorthodox visit to Pakistan's army headquarters, in recognition of Pakistan's long-standing support for the insurgents
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: On the ground, the overall picture is mixed
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: This year, Taliban-initiated attacks are reported to have fallen by 25 percent
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: ANSF mounted offensives four to five times more frequently than last year
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: At the same time
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as political scientist Jason Lyall observed, the recently-concluded fighting season - from April to October - "witnessed the appearance of large Taliban units on the battlefield" for the first time, with a tenth of all Afghan districts seeing "at least one major Taliban offensive"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Lyall also notes reports of over 1,000 insurgents on the battlefield,"numbers not seen since the Taliban's original push to capture Kabul during the 1992-96 civil war"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: While we should take these reports with a pinch of salt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: NATO commanders accuse their Afghan counterparts of exaggerating
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: they do point to a simple, stark fact
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The insurgency is far from broken
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it will be able to pressure the Afghan state for years to come
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In this context, the wave of insurgent attacks might be explained in several ways
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: First
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: , these attacks might be intended to drive a wedge between the Afghan government and its foreign patrons, encouraging the latter to abandon their allies more quickly
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As a Taliban spokesman put it bluntly:"Our objective is to force the foreigners to flee Kabul. Before, the foreigners were visible in the provinces. Now that they have limited more of their activities to Kabul, we have also gone to Kabul to target them there."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: To some extent, this has worked
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Many aid agencies have pulled out their staff, and restricted their movements
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Tarnished credibility
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Second
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the insurgents failed to seriously disrupt either round of this year's Afghan elections, as they had vowed to do, leaving their credibility somewhat tarnished
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Prominent attacks - publicised with videos - redress this issue, and project strength at the end of a fighting season
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They might also be ways of strengthening the insurgency's bargaining position in advance of any peace talks that gain momentum over the next year
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Third
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the insurgency is not a monolith
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: different parts of the Taliban might be responsible for different attacks
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Haqqani Network, a semi- autonomous group with close ties to Pakistani intelligence, has proven most effective at projecting suicide bombings into Kabul
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Haqqanis were blamed for the most deadly atrocity of the past month, the bombing of a volleyball game in which over 50 Afghans were killed
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In the past, moves towards dialogue between the Afghan government and the Taliban have been met with carefully targeted attacks intended less to strengthen bargaining positions than to disrupt such talks altogether
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: things look more precarious after that
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.label: no-unit
